conclusion: The cylinder is divided into two chambers by a diaphragm. Both chambers initially have the same pressure p, volume V, and temperature T. The diaphragm has mass m and rests on a ledge. The total height of the cylinder is 2H, and the total volume is 2V.

The diaphragm is subject to gravitational force mg and the pressure force from the gas in the lower chamber. When the piston moves upward, the pressure in the lower chamber increases until it overcomes the gravitational force on the diaphragm.
The diaphragm will start to leak when the pressure difference across it is sufficient to lift it. The pressure in the lower chamber must overcome the weight of the diaphragm.
Use the ideal gas law: pV = nRT. Since the temperature T is constant, the pressure is inversely proportional to the volume: p ‚àù 1/V.
Let V_0 be the volume of the lower chamber when leakage starts. The pressure in the lower chamber becomes p_0. The pressure in the upper chamber remains p.
The force balance on the diaphragm is: p_0 A - pA = mg where A is the cross-sectional area of the cylinder.
The area A can be related to the volume V and height H: A = V/H. The pressure difference is: (p_0 - p) V/H = mg. Rearrange to find p_0: p_0 = p + mgH/V.
Given x = mgH/pV, we have: p_0 = p(1 + x).
For the lower chamber: p_0 V_0 = pV. Substitute p_0: p(1 + x) V_0 = pV. Simplify: V_0 = V/(1 + x).
The volume of the lower chamber V_0 when the gas starts to leak between the chambers is: V_0 = V/(1 + x).
